tasks.description:
Research this topic thoroughly: {research_topic} using these keywords: {keywords}, considering {additional_information}.

IMPORTANT: Your goal is to gather 25-50 diverse, high-quality sources to ensure comprehensive coverage.

Detailed steps:
1. Identify primary keywords and concepts related to the topic
2. Break down the topic into at least 5-10 subtopics or aspects to explore
3. For each subtopic, use the search tool to find 5-10 highly relevant articles, studies, or reputable web pages
4. Ensure diversity in your sources, including academic journals, industry reports, news articles, government publications, and reputable websites
5. When possible, look for sources with differing perspectives or methodologies to provide a well-rounded view
6. For each source, use the website tool to extract key information, data points, evidence, and author/source details
7. Use multiple search queries with varied keywords to avoid bias in search results
8. Consider using advanced search operators to find specialized information (e.g., site:.edu, site:.gov, filetype:pdf)
9. CRITICAL - USE CITATION TOOL: For EVERY source you find, immediately add it using the CitationManager tool:
   - If source has DOI: {"operation": "add", "doi": "10.xxxx/xxxxx"}
   - If source has PMID: {"operation": "add", "pmid": "12345678"}
   - If source is a URL: {"operation": "add", "url": "https://..."}
   The tool will automatically:
   - Validate the source exists (prevents hallucinations)
   - Extract complete metadata (authors, title, journal, etc.)
   - Assign citation number [1], [2], etc.
   - Return formatted reference
10. NEVER manually create citations - always use the CitationManager tool
11. If tool reports "validation failed", the source doesn't exist - find a different source
12. After adding all sources, validate them: {"operation": "validate"}
12. Evaluate the credibility and recency of each source using criteria such as author expertise, publication reputation, peer-review status, and currency
13. Note the methodology used in research studies to assess the reliability of findings
14. Organize findings by theme or subtopic, with each data point explicitly linked to its citation
15. Consider perspectives with 5 depth
16. Focus on content type: detailed report
17. Document any conflicting evidence or viewpoints
18. Identify any gaps in the research that might require additional investigation
19. Aim to gather at least 25-50 high-quality sources to ensure comprehensive coverage of the topic

tasks.name: Comprehensive Research

tasks.description:
Perform an in-depth, comprehensive analysis of the research findings on: {research_topic} using keywords: {keywords} and considering {additional_information}.

IMPORTANT: Develop a completely original organizational framework based SOLELY on the research material, NOT on any predetermined structure or template.

Detailed steps:
1. Thoroughly review all research findings and sources provided by the researcher, ensuring you understand the breadth of the 25-50 sources
2. IMPORTANT: Develop a completely original organizational framework based SOLELY on the research material, NOT on any predetermined structure or template
3. Identify the main thematic areas that emerged from the research (could range from 3 to 15 major themes)
4. For each thematic area, create a hierarchy of main topics and subtopics
5. Consider whether a chronological, thematic, comparative, problem/solution, or other organizational approach best suits the material
6. Determine if certain topics deserve greater emphasis (more sections) based on the amount and quality of research available
7. Experiment with different possible structures before settling on the one that best presents the research findings
8. Do not feel constrained by traditional report formats - create a structure that best serves this specific topic and research
9. For each main theme, identify 3-7 key insights supported by multiple sources and specific evidence
10. Conduct a citation analysis to identify which sources are most frequently cited or considered most authoritative
11. Identify connections, relationships, and interdependencies between different themes and subtopics
12. Compare and contrast different perspectives, methodologies, or conclusions found across the sources
13. Always maintain the connection between insights and their original sources
14. When presenting data or claims, include the citation information in parentheses (Author, Year) [X], where X is the source's unique identifier
15. Keep track of all sources used for each section of your analysis, ensuring comprehensive coverage across the 25-50 sources
16. Analyze trends, patterns, and relationships between different aspects of the research topic
17. Evaluate the strength and quality of evidence supporting each major claim, noting methodological strengths or limitations
18. Identify gaps, contradictions, or areas needing further exploration
19. Assess research biases and limitations at a 5 level
20. Consider how the focus on detailed report impacts understanding
21. Create a detailed outline with recommended sections and subsections for the final report, with flexibility for 3-40 total sections based on what the material requires
22. Suggest effective ways to distribute citations throughout the report to ensure all 25-50 sources are utilized
23. Evaluate implications for different stakeholders
24. Suggest specific data points, statistics, or quotes that should be highlighted, always with attribution
25. Identify opportunities to present contrasting viewpoints with proper citation

tasks.description:
Create a comprehensive, professionally formatted research report on {research_topic} that is at least 2000-4000 words in length, incorporating findings related to {keywords} and addressing {additional_information}.

IMPORTANT: Determine the structure INDEPENDENTLY based on your analysis of the research material. Create between 3-40 sections/subsections total, organized in whatever way best presents the findings. DO NOT follow any predetermined template - let the content guide the structure.

Detailed steps:
1. Review all research findings and the analysis report in detail, noting all source materials
2. INDEPENDENTLY determine the optimal report structure based solely on the research material - do not follow a predetermined template
3. Create a structured outline with main sections and subsections before writing, with the number and organization determined entirely by the research findings
4. Use between 3-40 total sections and subsections, choosing a structure that best presents the research findings
5. Start with a detailed title using a markdown heading level 1 (#)
6. Consider whether the topic would benefit from a traditional structure or requires a more specialized approach
7. Create a table of contents reflecting your chosen structure
8. Write a comprehensive Executive Summary (3-4 paragraphs) that captures the essence of the report
9. Create main sections (using ## headings) with the number of sections determined by the topic's complexity and research findings
10. Develop subsections (using ### headings) where appropriate, allowing the material to guide the structure
11. For each paragraph, write at least 4-5 complete sentences that provide in-depth information and analysis
12. IMPORTANT: Include proper citations for EVERY claim, statistic, or piece of information using format (Author, Year) [X]
13. For direct quotes, use quotation marks and include page numbers if available: (Author, Year, p. X) [Y]
14. Aim to cite at least 25-30 different sources throughout the report to demonstrate thorough research
15. Distribute citations throughout the report rather than concentrating them in a few sections
16. Include specific data, statistics, and quotes from the research, with proper citation
17. Create detailed visualizations or tables where appropriate using markdown formatting, citing data sources
18. Ensure every claim is supported by evidence from the research with proper citation
19. Where appropriate, present multiple perspectives or contradictory findings on a topic, citing each source
20. Write a detailed Conclusion section that synthesizes all findings and offers future perspectives
21. Compile a properly formatted References section listing ALL sources cited in the text in alphabetical order
22. Format each reference entry according to a consistent citation style (APA, MLA, or Chicago)
23. Verify that every in-text citation has a corresponding entry in the References section
24. Ensure the report addresses how the 5 of research influenced the findings and how the detailed report focus shaped the analysis
25. Proofread the entire report for clarity, coherence, accuracy, grammar, and consistent formatting
26. Double-check all citations for accuracy and completeness
27. Ensure the total word count exceeds 2000 words at minimum
